Action: Implement an education programme with local schools
Develop a Biodiversity Communications strategy
Host/promote events for the community on biodiversity topics, e.g., talks & walks, tours, Heritage week, workshops, etc.
Work with the local community to promote biodiversity projects on site and within the local area
Develop biodiversity signage on site to inform visitors of the biodiversity present
Develop walking trails or other visitor infrastructure to highlight biodiversity onsite
Advertise and raise awareness of biodiversity actions within and beyond the sector
Provide training to staff on biodiversity & best practice
Promote engagement with biodiversity with staff
Ensure biodiversity is incorporated into all aspects of work
Undertake surveys to identify habitats and species to understand what is on site
Establish monitoring for species/habitats that are under threat or keystone species
Monitor species in line with relevant Species Action Plans or Threat Response Plans
Monitor habitat condition to update ecosystem accounts
Establish/Engage the local community or volunteer group that are interested in biodiversity monitoring
Involve citizen scientists in monitoring of habitats/species
Promote initiatives that involve citizen science, especially involving the local community
Provide a central database for biodiversity data to be stored and easily accessed
Submit data to the National Biodiversity Data Centre and other relevant organisations
Ensure data collected meets data standards and follows relevant guidelines
Make use of open biodiversity data to inform decisions
Create nesting or food resources for pollinators/invertebrates
Create habitat corridors between existing habitats
Create pockets of new habitat throughout the site
Create/Improve pond habitats
Identify and map the locations of invasive species
Remove invasive species from the site, adhering to correct removal methods to reduce risk of spread
Develop a plan for monitoring and managing invasive species
Raise awareness of invasive species and keep up to date on updates from NBDC
Manage hedgerows in a biodiversity-friendly manner
Manage areas in a pollinator-friendly manner and report to the AIPP
Minimise the use of chemical pesticides, insecticides, herbicides, fungicides, rodenticides, etc. on site
Manage existing water features (ponds, lakes, rivers) in a biodiversity-friendly manner
Implement nature-based solutions around the site
Encourage farmers to engage with biodiversity-friendly management
Manage in a positive way for native species
Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Use a natural-capital accounting approach to manage land for biodiversity
Restore and improve wetland and waterbody habitats
Restore hedgerows around the site to improve ecological connectivity
Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Identify opportunities to restore habitats
